ny: Motero, Khamenei anati, mapangano onse a mtendere akale - monga Pangano la Oslo la 1993, njira yothetsera mkangano wa Israyeli ndi Palestina yokhala ndi maiko aŵiri, ndi pulani ya pulezidenti wakale wa United States Donald Trump yotchedwa Pangano la Zaka Zana "ndi yopanda pake".

en: President Ebrahim Raisi, Irans military commanders and senior officials also attended the rallies in which people were allowed to march through the streets, the first time since the outbreak of the coronavirus pandemic two years ago.
ny: Pulezidenti Ebrahim Raisi, akuluakulu a asilikali a Iran ndi akuluakulu ena a boma nawonso anapezeka pamisonkhano imene anthu analoledwa kuyenda m'misewu, kwa nthawi yoyamba kuchokera pamene mliri wa coronavirus unayamba zaka ziwiri zapitazo.

en: Iran's Jerusalem Day rallies are held annually in support of Palestinians, who want East Jerusalem as the capital of a future state in territories captured by Israel in a 1967 war, on the last Friday of the Muslim fasting month of Ramadan.
ny: Misonkhano ya tsiku la Yerusalemu ku Iran imachitika chaka chilichonse pothandiza anthu a ku Palestina, omwe amafuna kuti East Jerusalem ikhale likulu la dziko la mtsogolo m'madera omwe analandidwa ndi Israeli mu nkhondo ya 1967, Lachisanu lomaliza la mwezi wa Ramadan wa kusala kudya kwa Asilamu.

en: "Stop your vicious deeds. You know well that we are people of action and reaction," Revolutionary Guards commander Hossein Salami, addressing Israel, told demonstrators in Tehran.
ny: "Lekani kuchita zinthu zoipa. Mukudziwa bwino kuti ndife anthu ochita zinthu ndi ochita zinthu zosemphana ndi zofuna za anthu", anatero mtsogoleri wa gulu la asilikali oteteza chipanduko, Hossein Salami, polankhula ndi Israyeli, kwa anthu omwe anali kuchita zionetsero ku Tehran.

en: "Our responses are painful. You create conditions for your own destruction. We will not leave you alone ...You know better than me what will befall you if you take evil action."
ny: "Mayankho athu ndi opweteka. Mumapanga mikhalidwe yakuwonongeka kwanu. Sitidzakusiyani nokha...Mumadziwa bwino kuposa ine zomwe zingakuchitikireni ngati mutenga zochita zoipa".

en: Iran's military has vowed to retaliate harshly against any attack by Israel, which has often voiced concern over the Iranian nuclear program. Tehran says the program is for peaceful purposes only.
ny: Asilikali a Iran alonjeza kuti adzabwezera mwankhanza ku chiwonongeko chilichonse cha Israeli, chomwe nthawi zambiri chimakhala ndi nkhawa ndi pulogalamu ya nyukiliya ya Iran. Tehran akuti pulogalamuyi ndi ya mtendere zokha.

en: Israel, whose existence the Islamic Republic does not recognize, has long threatened military action against Iran if talks between Tehran and world powers fail to curb Iranian nuclear activity. Iran says its nuclear ambitions are peaceful.
ny: Israel, yomwe kulibe kuulula kwa Islamic Republic, kwa nthawi yaitali yaopseza kuti idzachita nkhondo ndi Iran ngati zokambirana pakati pa Tehran ndi maulamuliro a dziko lapansi zalephera kuletsa ntchito za nyukiliya za Iran.

en: In February, the Islamic Republic unveiled its "Kheibar Buster" missile with a range of 1,450 km (900 miles).
ny: Mu February, dziko la Islamic Republic linatulutsa nyukiliya yake yotchedwa "Kheibar Buster" yokhala ndi mtunda wa makilomita 1,450.

en: Iran, which has one of the biggest missile programs in the Middle East, says its ballistic missiles have a range of up to 2,000 km (1,200 miles) and are capable of reaching its arch-foe Israel and U.S. bases in the region.
ny: Iran, yomwe ili ndi imodzi mwa mapulogalamu akuluakulu a zida za nkhondo ku Middle East, imanena kuti zida zake za nkhondo zili ndi mtunda wa makilomita 2,000 ndipo zimatha kufika ku Israel ndi ku mabwalo a nkhondo a ku America m'derali.

en: Kheibar refers to an ancient Jewish oasis in the Arabian Peninsula's Hijaz region that was overrun by Muslim warriors in the 7th century.
ny: Kheibar amatanthauza malo akale achiyuda m'dera la Hijaz ku Arabia, amene anawonongedwa ndi asilikali achisilamu m'zaka za m'ma 700 C.E.

en: Tehran regards its ballistic missile program as an important deterrent against the United States, Israel and other adversaries, and has rejected Western demands to halt it.
ny: Tehran amaona kuti mapulogalamu ake a zida zankhondo za balistic ndi ofunika kwambiri kuletsa dziko la United States, Israel ndi adani ena, ndipo wakana zimene mayiko a kumadzulo amafuna kuti asiye ntchitoyi.

en: Over the past year, Iran and the United States have engaged in fitful, indirect talks in Vienna to revive a 2015 nuclear deal that then-President Donald Trump reneged on in 2018 and that Iran, in turn, began violating in 2019.
ny: Chaka chathachi, Iran ndi United States akhala akukambirana mosadukiza ku Vienna kuti akhazikitsenso mgwirizano wa zida za nyukiliya wa mu 2015 womwe Purezidenti wa nthawiyo a Donald Trump anasiya mu 2018 ndipo Iran, idayamba kuphwanya mu 2019.

en: Under the 2015 deal, Iran agreed to limit its nuclear program in return for relief from economic sanctions.
ny: Malinga ndi pangano la mu 2015, Iran inavomera kuchepetsa pulogalamu yake ya nyukiliya pofuna kuti ikhale ndi ufulu wochotsera anthu chilango cha zachuma.

en: While they appeared close to resurrecting the deal in March, talks stalled over last-minute Russian demands and whether Washington might drop Iran's Revolutionary Guards from its Foreign Terrorist Organization list.
ny: Ngakhale kuti anaoneka ngati ali pafupi kubwezeretsa mgwirizanowo mu March, zokambirana zinagwera pansi chifukwa cha zimene Russia inafuna pa mphindi yomaliza ndiponso ngati Washington ingachotse gulu la asilikali oteteza chipanduko la Iran pa mndandanda wa mabungwe omwe amachititsa zigawenga m'mayiko ena.

en: As Fewer Americans Attend Church, Can Coffee Shops Fill the Void?
ny: Pamene Anthu a ku America Akuchepa Kupita ku Tchalitchi, Kodi Malo Ogulitsa Kofi Angadzaze Kusoŵeka Kumeneko?

en: Churches and other houses of worship have historically played critical social and political functions in American society. But fewer people are attending religious services, and the decline of churches and other houses of worship threatens to leave a void that could potentially be filled by coffee shops.
ny: Koma anthu ochepa akupita ku misonkhano ya chipembedzo, ndipo kuchepa kwa matchalitchi ndi nyumba zina zopemphereramo kukuopseza kusiya mphepo imene ingadzazidwe ndi malo ogulitsira khofi.

en: "For so much of American history, the church has really been — or their congregations have really been — essential, providing an unheralded role in providing cohesion and connectedness in communities … encouraging civic engagement and political participation," says Daniel Cox, director of the Survey Center on American Life and a senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute.
ny: "Kwa nthaŵi yaitali m'mbiri ya America, tchalitchi chakhala chofunika kwambiri, kapena mipingo yawo yakhala yofunika kwambiri, ndipo yakhala ndi mbali yofunika kwambiri pa kulimbikitsa mgwirizano ndi kugwirizana m'madera... kulimbikitsa anthu kuchita nawo zinthu zachikhalidwe ndi ndale", akutero Daniel Cox, mkulu wa bungwe lofufuza za moyo wa anthu a ku America ndiponso katswiri wa bungwe la American Enterprise Institute.

en: "It was not happenstance or luck that the civil rights movement emerged out of the church," Cox says.
ny: "Sichinali chochitika chongochitika mwangozi kapena mwayi kuti gulu la ufulu wachibadwidwe linachokera m'tchalitchi", akutero Cox.

en: "And you see that cross-culturally … whether it's in predominantly white rural communities, in the suburbs, wherever, churches have historically been really, really important."
ny: "Ndipo mumaona kuti m'zikhalidwe zosiyanasiyana... kaya ndi m'madera akumidzi kumene kuli azungu ambiri, m'midzi ya kumidzi, kulikonse, matchalitchi akhala ofunika kwambiri m'mbiri yonse".

en: Churches and other houses of worship have also played a role in helping immigrants assimilate once they arrive in America, Cox says.
ny: Cox akuti matchalitchi ndi nyumba zina zopemphereramo zingathandizenso anthu osamukira kudziko lina kuti azolowere zinthu zina akangofika ku America.

en: In 1999, 70% of Americans said they belonged to a church, mosque or synagogue.
ny: Mu 1999, 70% ya anthu a ku America anati anali a tchalitchi, mzikiti kapena sunagoge.

en: By 2020, that number had dropped to 47%. A 2019 survey found that only about three in 10 Americans say they attend weekly religious services.
ny: Pofika mu 2020, chiwerengerocho chinatsika kufika pa 47%. Kafukufuku wina amene anachitika mu 2019 anasonyeza kuti anthu atatu okha mwa anthu 10 alionse a ku America ndi amene amanena kuti amapita ku misonkhano ya chipembedzo mlungu uliwonse.

en: Third places  Lack of involvement and affiliation with churches, mosques and synagogues means people might be missing out on what urban sociologist Ray Oldenburg dubbed as "third places" — public gathering spots that offer something that home, the "first place," and work, the "second place," might not.
ny: Malo achitatu Kusakhudzidwa ndi mipingo, misikiti ndi masunagoge kumatanthauza kuti anthu angasoŵe zimene katswiri wa zachikhalidwe cha anthu a m'mizinda Ray Oldenburg anazitcha kuti "malo achitatu"  malo osonkhanira anthu ambiri amene amapereka zinthu zimene panyumba, "malo oyamba", ndi kuntchito, "malo achiŵiri", sangapereke.

en: Oldenburg argued that third places are critical to a communitys social vitality.
ny: Oldenburg ananena kuti malo achitatu ndi ofunika kwambiri kuti anthu azikhala ndi moyo wabwino.

en: An October 2021 survey conducted by the American Survey Center found that commercial spaces like coffee houses foster trust and connection in American communities and could help fill the void left by churches.
ny: Kafukufuku wa mu October 2021 wochitidwa ndi American Survey Center anapeza kuti malo ogulitsa zinthu monga malo ogulitsira khofi amalimbikitsa kukhulupirirana ndi kugwirizana m'madera a ku America ndipo angathandize kudzaza mpata umene tchalitchi chimasiya.

en: "If you're a regular at a cafe, the barista may know what you usually order, and they can make it for you, and that feels good," says clinical psychologist Dr. Maria Espinola, an assistant professor in the Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Neuroscience at the University of Cincinnati College of Medicine.
ny: "Ngati mumakonda kupita ku cafe, woperekera zakudyayo angadziŵe zimene mumakonda kuitanitsa, ndipo angakupangireni, ndipo zimenezi zimam'sangalatsa", akutero katswiri wa zamaganizo Dr. Maria Espinola, pulofesa wothandiza pa Dipatimenti ya Psychiatry ndi Behavioral Neuroscience pa University of Cincinnati College of Medicine.

en: "It feels good to be recognized, to know that people are expecting you, to know that people care about you, to know that you belong, because the need for belonging and human connection is a fundamental need that we all have, and it's important to have that fulfilled in different ways," Espinola says.
ny: Espinola anati: "N'zosangalatsa kudziwa kuti anthu akukuyembekezera, kudziwa kuti anthu amakukonda, kudziwa kuti ndiwe wofunika, chifukwa chakuti kufunika kokhala munthu wofunika ndi kugwirizana ndi anthu ena ndi chinthu chofunika kwambiri chimene tonsefe timafuna.

en: "So, places like third places can allow us to do that."
ny: "Choncho, malo ngati malo achitatu angatithandize kuchita zimenezo".

en: In the past, churches and other houses of worship have been a third place for many Americans.
ny: Kale, matchalitchi ndi nyumba zina zopemphereramo zinali malo achitatu kwa anthu ambiri a ku America.

en: In 2019, 67% of people surveyed said they have a third place — a coffee shop, bar, restaurant, park or other place in their community that they visit regularly.
ny: Mu 2019, 67% ya anthu omwe anafunsidwa ananena kuti ali ndi malo achitatu  malo ogulitsira khofi, bala, malo odyera, paki kapena malo ena m'dera lawo omwe amawachezera nthawi zonse.

en: That number dropped to 56% in 2021 — a number that could have been affected by the COVID-19 pandemic.
ny: Chiwerengerochi chinatsika kufika pa 56% mu 2021  chiwerengero chimene chikanawonongedwa ndi mliri wa COVID-19.

en: "What we found was that people who had a third place were much more connected to their community," says Cox. "They're much more likely to engage in other activities there.
ny: Cox anati: "Tinaona kuti anthu amene anali ndi malo achitatu anali ogwirizana kwambiri ndi anthu a m'dera lawo.

en: They are much more trusting of their neighbors. There's a whole great array of positive social outcomes that were connected to having a third place … and for a lot of Americans, it's a coffee shop or a cafe."
ny: Iwo amakhulupirira kwambiri anansi awo. Pali zinthu zambiri zabwino zimene zimachitika chifukwa chokhala ndi malo achitatu... ndipo kwa anthu ambiri a ku America, malowa ndi malo omwera khofi".

en: What coffee shops have in their favor is that they can be found almost everywhere, all over the country, and anyone who wants to can stop by regularly.
ny: Chomwe chimapangitsa malo ogulitsira khofi kukhala abwino ndichoti amapezeka pafupifupi kulikonse, m'dziko lonselo, ndipo aliyense amene akufuna angaloŵe nthaŵi zonse.

en: And many are open most days of the week.
ny: Ndipo ambiri ali otseguka masiku ambiri a mlungu.

en: Cox says even brief coffee shop encounters can increase a sense of belonging.
ny: Cox akuti ngakhale kukumana kwa kanthaŵi kochepa m'malo ogulitsira khofi kungawonjezere kumverera kwa kukhala nawo.

en: "I think there's a lot of potential here, and a lot of it is unrealized potential," Cox says.
ny: Cox anati: "Ndikuganiza kuti pali zinthu zambiri zimene zingachitike, ndipo zambiri mwa zinthu zimenezi sizinachitike".

en: "But in terms of what they could do, there's a lot there.
ny: "Koma ponena za zimene iwo akanatha kuchita, pali zambiri kumeneko.

en: I've been in places where the same group of folks come in there to play chess.
ny: Ndakhala ndikukhala m'malo amene gulu la anthu omwewo amabwera kudzaseŵera maseŵera a chess.

en: Or they have their informal bunch of retirees. … They just got together, and they talked and chatted and caught up with each other. … I don't know where else they would have gone — maybe a church, but maybe not — to share information, to encourage each other to maybe get involved in an activity.
ny: Kapena ali ndi gulu lawo la anthu opuma pantchito.... Anangokumana, ndipo ankalankhula ndi kucheza ndi kukumana wina ndi mnzake.... Sindikudziwa komwe akanapita  mwina tchalitchi, koma mwina osati  kuti agawane zambiri, kuti alimbikitsane kuti mwina achite nawo ntchito.

en: And I think that is what is so powerful about coffee shops."
ny: Ndipo ndikuganiza kuti chimenecho ndicho chinthu champhamvu kwambiri pa malo ogulitsira khofi".

en: What US Mayors Are Most Worried About After the Pandemic
ny: Zomwe Meya aku US Akuda nkhawa kwambiri pambuyo pa mliriwu

en: Americas mayors are most concerned about the lingering mental health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic, according to a nationwide survey of 126 mayors conducted during the summer of 2021.
ny: Mayors a ku America ali ndi nkhawa kwambiri ndi mavuto a m'maganizo omwe ali ndi mliri wa COVID-19, malinga ndi kafukufuku wa mayiko onse wa mayors 126 omwe anachitika mchilimwe cha 2021.

en: The respondents headed cities with at least 75,000 residents. The local leaders are still focused on traditional issues such as violent crime, the economy and infrastructure, but they are most concerned about the pandemics long-term impact on the mental health of their constituents.
ny: Atsogoleri a m'mizinda ya m'dzikoli akuganizirabe za nkhani zachikhalidwe monga zachiwawa, zachuma ndi zomangamanga, koma akuda nkhaŵa kwambiri ndi mmene mliriwu udzakhudzire anthu awo pa thanzi lawo la maganizo.

en: Mental health was top of mind for Michael Udine when he was sworn in as mayor of Broward County, Florida, in November 2021.
ny: Michael Udine ankaona kuti thanzi lake ndi lofunika kwambiri pamene analumbidwa kukhala meya wa chigawo cha Broward, ku Florida, mu November 2021.

en: "Everything that was a potential issue pre-pandemic has pretty much been exacerbated by the pandemic," he says. "There were issues going into the pandemic, and it was becoming more and more important on everyone's radar screen about the mental health of people of all ages. And I think the pandemic pretty much supercharged those issues."
ny: "Zonse zimene zinali vuto la mliri usanachitike zawonjezeka kwambiri ndi mliriwu", iye akutero. "Panali mavuto amene analowa m'mbali mwa mliriwu, ndipo zinali kukhala zofunika kwambiri kwa aliyense pankhani ya thanzi la maganizo la anthu a misinkhu yonse. Ndipo ndikuganiza kuti mliriwu unakulitsa kwambiri mavuto amenewo".

en: It is not unusual for large outbreaks of disease to have a negative impact on mental health, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which reports that rates of anxiety and depressive disorders among adults increased during the pandemic.
ny: Malinga ndi zimene bungwe la Centers for Disease Control and Prevention linanena, si zachilendo kuti matenda aakulu aziyambitsa mavuto m'maganizo. Bungweli linanena kuti anthu achikulire omwe ankada nkhawa komanso kuvutika maganizo, ankachulukirachulukira pa nthawi ya mliriwu.

en: The pandemic has also adversely influenced the emotional and mental health of about one-third of Americas youth.
ny: Mliriwu wawononga maganizo ndi thanzi la pafupifupi gawo limodzi mwa magawo atatu a achinyamata a ku America.

en: "What we've seen is just such anxiety, kids who wouldn't ordinarily have a meltdown, because it's so much change and difficulty adjusting to transitions," Maryland psychologist Mary Karapetian Alvord told VOA last month. "We've also seen a lot more sadness and depression."
ny: "Zimene tawona ndi nkhaŵa yaikulu, ana amene kaŵirikaŵiri sangakhale ndi vuto la kusokonezeka maganizo, chifukwa chakuti pali kusintha kwakukulu ndi zovuta kuzoloŵera kusintha", anatero katswiri wa zamaganizo wa ku Maryland Mary Karapetian Alvord kwa VOA mwezi watha. "Tawonanso chisoni ndi kupsinjika maganizo kwambiri".

en: Early on in the pandemic, mayors were more focused on city operations, budget shortfalls and the threat the pandemic posed to small businesses, according to David Glick, an associate professor of political science at Boston University and a co-author of the 2021 Menino Survey of Mayors.
ny: Kumayambiriro kwa mliriwu, meya anali okhudzidwa kwambiri ndi kayendetsedwe ka mzinda, kusowa kwa bajeti komanso chiwopsezo chomwe mliriwu udabweretsa kwa mabizinesi ang'onoang'ono, malinga ndi a David Glick, pulofesa wothandizira wa sayansi yandale ku yunivesite ya Boston komanso wolemba nawo kafukufuku wa 2021 Menino wa Meya.

en: "Some of those concerns still remain, but what we saw more of in 2021 … is concern about some of the long-term impacts on individual residents," Glick says. "Concerns about polarization over vaccines and just people being pushed to their limits … and certainly less on their city budgets and revenues and having to cut programs and some of those types of things that were probably more top of mind earlier in the pandemic."
ny: "Zinthu zina zomwe zimadetsa nkhawa zikadalipobe, koma zomwe tidawona zambiri mu 2021... ndi nkhawa za zina mwazomwe zimakhudza nzika zapadera, " akutero Glick. "Kudandaula za kupotoza katemera komanso anthu omwe akukakamiza malire awo... ndipo mosakayikira zochepa pamalipiro ndi ndalama zamzinda wawo ndikuyenera kudula mapulogalamu ndi zina mwazinthu zomwe mwina zinali zofunika kwambiri koyambirira kwa mliriwu. "

en: Over half of mayors, 52%, are worried about "lingering mental health challenges and trauma," according to the survey. Additionally, more than one-third of mayors, 37%, are worried about learning loss among young people.
ny: Pafupifupi theka la meya, 52%, akuda nkhaŵa ndi "zovuta za maganizo ndi mavuto ena", malinga ndi kafukufukuyu.Kuphatikiza apo, oposa gawo limodzi mwa magawo atatu a meya, 37%, akuda nkhaŵa ndi kuchepa kwa maphunziro pakati pa achinyamata.

en: "Second only to mental health and trauma, and they're probably not totally independent concerns," Glick says. "It is part of that shift of mayors concerns from immediate threats to businesses closing and people getting sick, to some of these longer-term consequences that are going to persist in the future. And learning loss among their students, theyre worried it's going to persist for many, many, many years into the future. It's hard to make up for."
ny: "Kupita kwa thanzi la maganizo ndi kupwetekedwa maganizo, ndipo mwina si nkhani yodziimira payokha", akutero Glick. "Ndi mbali ya kusintha kwa nkhaŵa za meya kuchokera ku ziwopsezo zapanthaŵi yomweyo kupita ku kutsekedwa kwa mabizinesi ndi anthu odwala, kupita ku zina mwa zotsatira za nthaŵi yaitali zimene zidzapitirirabe m'tsogolo. Ndipo ophunzira awo akumaopa kuti kutayika kwa kuphunzira kudzapitirirabe kwa zaka zambiri m'tsogolo. N'zovuta kutero".

en: According to the survey, other top concerns for Americas mayors include the financial insecurity of low-income residents (33%), the closing of small businesses (29%) and increased crime and violence (26%).
ny: Malinga ndi kafukufukuyu, anthu ena amene amada nkhaŵa kwambiri ndi mayors a ku America ndi kusatetezeka kwa ndalama kwa anthu okhala ndi ndalama zochepa (33%), kutsekedwa kwa mabizinesi ang'onoang'ono (29%) ndi kuchuluka kwa upandu ndi chiwawa (26%).

en: Just 7% of mayors are worried about the shift to remote work and the long-term impact that could have on outmigration — people moving away from their cities.
ny: Ndi 7% yokha ya meya amene akuda nkhaŵa ndi kusinthira ntchito kutali ndi zotsatira za nthaŵi yaitali zimene zingachitike pa kusamuka  anthu akuchoka m'mizinda yawo.

en: The $350 billion in funding from the American Rescue Plan to local and state governments could help mayors address some of their concerns. The survey found that 78% of mayors believe the money will allow them to make meaningful change.
ny: Ndalama zokwana madola 350 biliyoni zochokera ku American Rescue Plan zopita ku maboma a m'madera ndi a m'zigawo zingathandize kuti meya athetse mavuto awo. Kafukufukuyu anapeza kuti 78% ya meya amakhulupirira kuti ndalamazo zidzawathandiza kuti asinthe zinthu.

en: "What we're seeing is a large majority are using it for things they consider to be transformative and will make major changes to their cities," Glick says, "instead of feeling obligated or feeling the necessity to use it to plug up over-budget gaps to keep the doors open and the lights on."
ny: "Zimene tikuona n'zakuti ambiri akugwiritsa ntchito ndalamazo pa zinthu zimene akuona kuti n'zosintha ndipo adzasintha kwambiri mizinda yawo", akutero Glick, "m'malo momva kuti akuyenera kapena kuti ayenera kuzigwiritsa ntchito pochepetsa ndalama zimene akuwononga kuti zitseko zisatseke ndiponso kuti magetsi azigwira ntchito".

en: Young Compete Against Old in Hottest US Rental Market in a Decade
ny: Achinyamata Akulimbana ndi Okalamba M'misika Yotentha Kwambiri Yogona Nyumba ku US M'zaka Khumi

en: Renting an apartment can be a challenge for new college graduates who are facing the hottest U.S. rental market in a decade, along with some unexpected competition from millennials — people aged 24 to 40 — and even baby boomers — the over-57 club.
ny: Kubwereka nyumba kungakhale kovuta kwa anthu amene angomaliza kumene maphunziro awo ku koleji, amene akuyang'anizana ndi msika wa nyumba za lendi wotentha kwambiri ku United States m'zaka khumi zapitazi, limodzi ndi mpikisano wina wosayembekezereka wochokera kwa anthu a m'badwo wa zaka zikwizikwi  anthu a zaka 24 mpaka 40  ngakhalenso anthu a m'badwo wa "baby boomers"  gulu la anthu oposa zaka 57 zakubadwa.

en: "You have aging millennials who are creating families who should be moving from rental situations into ownership but, because of the lack of housing supply, that has been stopped in a lot of instances. And so, what you see is the aging millennial population continues to rent," says Doug Ressler, manager of business intelligence at Yardi-Matrix, a commercial real estate data and research firm.
ny: "M'badwo wa zaka zikwizikwi umene ukuyamba kupanga mabanja, umene uyenera kukhala ndi nyumba zawo zokha, koma chifukwa cha kusowa kwa nyumba, nthaŵi zambiri zimenezi zaletsedwa.

en: "It's not just about millennials, it's not just about [Gen] Z [people under 24], we also see that boomers are making a transition, he added. "Their percentage of moving into rental properties is growing in the last five years."
ny: "Sikuti ndi za millennials okha, si za [Gen] Z [anthu osakwana zaka 24], tikuonanso kuti anthu a m'badwo wa boomers akusintha, anawonjezera. "Chiwerengero chawo cha anthu amene akusamukira ku nyumba zogona chikukula m'zaka zisanu zapitazi".

en: There are a variety of reasons older people are opting for rentals, according to Ressler.
ny: Malinga ndi Ressler, pali zifukwa zosiyanasiyana zimene anthu okalamba amasankhira nyumba zogona.

en: "They've lived in a home for so long and they want to be able to reduce their expenses on a fixed income," he says. "They want to live in a social cohort, like a retirement community, and things like that where it's much more socially amenable to them."
ny: "Akakhala m'nyumba kwa nthaŵi yaitali ndipo amafuna kuti athe kuchepetsa ndalama zimene amawononga pa ndalama zawo zosakhalitsa", iye akutero. "Amakhala m'nyumba za anthu ena, monga nyumba za anthu opuma pantchito, ndi zina zotero kumene anthuwo amavomereza kwambiri".

en: The asking price of apartment rentals was up 10.7% in September 2021 compared to last year at the same time, according to the National Association of Realtors (NAR).
ny: Mtengo wofunsira nyumba zogona unakwera ndi 10.7% mu September 2021 poyerekeza ndi nthawi yomweyi chaka chatha, malinga ndi National Association of Realtors (NAR).

en: "It's a hot market. We have never seen this market so hot in the last decade," says Gay Cororaton, NARs senior economist and director of housing and commercial research. "The average rent growth, year-over-year, is about 3-to-5%. We're seeing 11% rent growth now, so, clearly, way above trends weve had in the past."
ny: "Ndi msika wotentha kwambiri. Sitinaonepo msika wotentha chonchi m'zaka khumi zapitazi", akutero Gay Cororaton, katswiri wa zachuma wamkulu wa NAR ndi mkulu wa kafukufuku wa nyumba ndi malonda. "Kukula kwa lendi, chaka ndi chaka, kuli pafupifupi 3-5%.

en: Renters are feeling the squeeze because the COVID-19 pandemic caused supply chain issues, slowing down home building in the United States. Instead of the usual 5-to-6 month supply of available single-family homes, supply dropped below two months in January 2021. The lack of housing supply means millennials are having a harder time buying a single-family home, which has been the traditional trajectory in the past.
ny: Anthu omwe akubwereka nyumba akuvutika chifukwa cha mliri wa COVID-19 womwe wachititsa kuti pakhale mavuto a supply chain, zomwe zachepetsa ntchito yomanga nyumba ku United States. M'malo mwa kupereka nyumba za banja limodzi kwa miyezi 5 mpaka 6, zoperekazo zinatsika pansi pa miyezi iwiri mu Januware 2021.

en: "The whole building industry was beset by supply chain issues," Cororaton says. "Shipments couldn't come in, the price of lumber was rising, manufacturing slowed, workers could not come in [to work], so you have shortages of frames, appliances. So, essentially, just a short supply."
ny: "Makampani onse omanga nyumba anali ndi mavuto a kayendetsedwe ka katundu", akutero Cororaton. "Zinthu zimene zinkatumizidwa sizinkaloledwa, mtengo wa mitengo ya mitengo unali kukwera, kupanga zinthu kunayamba kuchepa, antchito sakanatha kubwera [kukachita ntchito], chotero munali kusowa kwa mafelemu, zipangizo zamagetsi.

en: The housing supply got even tighter during the pandemic as more investors put their money into housing, according to Cororaton, while existing homeowners looked for second homes.
ny: Nyumba zopezeka zinayamba kuchepa kwambiri panthawi ya mliriwu pamene anthu ambiri omwe amagulitsa nyumba anayamba kukagula nyumba, malinga ndi Cororaton, pamene eni nyumba omwe analipo kale ankafunafuna nyumba zina.

en: "With the pandemic, there was also a big demand for second homes, for vacation homes. Typically, vacation homes accounted for just about 5% [of the market]," she says. "Early this summer they rose to about 8%. So again, strong demand and strong imbalance of demand and supply caused home prices to rise, made them less affordable."
ny: "Pamene mliriwu unkafika, anthu ambiri ankafuna nyumba za anthu amene ankafuna kukhala m'nyumba zina, nyumba za anthu amene ankafuna kukhala pa tchuthi. Nthawi zambiri nyumba za anthu amene ankafuna kukhala pa tchuthi zinali ndi malo okwana 5% okha [m'misika yonseyo]", iye anati. "Kumayambiriro kwa chilimwe chino, nyumba zimenezi zinakula kufika pafupifupi 8%.

en: The hottest rental markets right now are in the West and South. More renters are moving to Dallas and Houston in Texas, followed by Atlanta, Georgia; New York; Los Angeles; Austin, Texas; Phoenix, Arizona; and Washington, D.C., according to NAR.
ny: Malinga ndi NAR, anthu ambiri amene akugulitsa nyumba m'madera otentha kwambiri ndi a kumadzulo ndi kum'mwera kwa dzikoli.

en: Cororaton expects the coming year to be a little better but says the housing shortage is likely to continue for the next few years.
ny: Cororaton akuyembekeza kuti chaka chamawa chidzakhala chabwino pang'ono koma akuti kusowa kwa nyumba kudzapitirirabe kwa zaka zingapo zikubwerazi.

en: "You know, the old adage of moving from rentals into homeownership, that whole polemic may be changing," says Ressler. "The sweet spot was always the millennials, and now the millennials are being replaced by the [Gen] Zs, but the millennials are staying longer and the Zs are coming on board, and now you've got the demographic of the boomers … What it means is a very profitable and dynamic [rental] market that's going to continue to grow."
ny: "Mukudziwa, mawu akale akuti kusamuka kuchoka ku nyumba za lendi kupita ku nyumba za eni, mkangano wonsewo ukhoza kusintha", akutero Ressler. "Malo abwino anali a millennials, ndipo tsopano millennials akuchotsedwa ndi [Gen] Zs, koma millennials akukhala nthawi yaitali ndipo Zs akubwera pa bolodi, ndipo tsopano muli ndi chiwerengero cha anthu a boomers... Chimene chimatanthauza ndi msika wopindulitsa kwambiri ndi wolimba [wa lendi] umene upitiriza kukula. "

en: Are COVID-19 Restrictions Stunting Children’s Immune Systems?
ny: Kodi Kuletsa Ana Kutenga Katemera wa COVID-19 Kumapweteketsa Maganizo a Ana?

en: Some medical experts have expressed concern that COVID-19 preventative measures, like masking and remote schooling, are potentially weakening childrens immune systems by shielding them from the usual childhood illnesses.
ny: Akatswiri ena azachipatala anena kuti njira zopewera COVID-19, monga kuvala chigoba ndi kusukulu, zingafooketse chitetezo cha m'thupi cha ana powateteza ku matenda omwe amachitika kawirikawiri.

en: "There are a lot of reasons to believe that kids need to be exposed to things to keep their immunity complex, so that should they encounter something very dangerous, they have aspects of their immunity that might cross over and help protect them against those things," says Sara Sawyer, a professor of molecular, cellular and developmental biology at the University of Colorado Boulder.
ny: "Pali zifukwa zambiri zokhulupirira kuti ana afunika kukhala ndi zinthu zina kuti akhalebe ndi chitetezo cha m'thupi, kotero kuti ngati angakumane ndi chinthu choopsa kwambiri, ali ndi mbali zina za chitetezo cha m'thupi zimene zingawateteze ku zinthu zimenezo", akutero Sara Sawyer, pulofesa wa sayansi ya maselo, maselo ndi chitukuko pa yunivesite ya Colorado Boulder.

en: At birth, vulnerable infants get antibodies from their mothers breast milk, which helps protect them until they can build their own immunity.
ny: Ana amene amabadwa ali ndi vutoli amatenga ma antibodies kuchokera mkaka wa mayi awo, womwe umawateteza mpaka atayamba kudziteteza.

en: Its no accident that babies start putting things in their mouths as soon as they gain enough dexterity to pick things up.  "They're doing that because they're sampling the environment and building their immunity. That's an evolutionary trait," Sawyer says.
ny: Sawyer anati: "Ana amayamba kuika zinthu m'kamwa mwawo akangofika pokhoza kunyamula zinthu.

en: "Theyre exposing their body to germs in a certain, level way to build their immunity.
ny: "Amalandira tizilombo toyambitsa matenda m'thupi mwawo m'njira inayake kuti akhale ndi chitetezo cha m'thupi.

en: So, some people would argue that childhood illnesses, like colds and stomach bugs, build our immunity so that when more dangerous things come along, we're prepared and we don't get as sick from those more dangerous things."
ny: Choncho, anthu ena anganene kuti matenda a paubwana, monga chimfine ndi matenda a m'mimba, amatithandiza kukhala ndi chitetezo cha m'thupi kuti zinthu zoopsa zikafika, tikhale okonzeka ndipo tisadwale chifukwa cha zinthu zoopsazo".

en: Even before the pandemic, epidemiological evidence suggested that children in more developed countries, where handwashing and the use of sanitizer are more prevalent, might have less-developed immune systems compared to kids in developing nations who are routinely exposed to more bacteria, viruses and allergens.
ny: Ngakhale mliriwu usanachitike, umboni wa matendawa unasonyeza kuti ana a m'mayiko otukuka, kumene kusamba m'manja ndi kugwiritsa ntchito mankhwala ophera tizilombo toyambitsa matenda n'kofala, angakhale ndi chitetezo cha m'thupi chochepa poyerekeza ndi ana a m'mayiko osauka amene nthawi zonse amakhala ndi mabakiteriya, mavairasi ndi zinthu zina zochititsa matenda.

en: This makes kids in more industrialized countries more vulnerable to developing autoimmune diseases, according to whats known as the "hygiene hypothesis."
ny: Zimenezi zimachititsa ana a m'maiko otukuka kukhala ndi matenda a chitetezo cha m'thupi, malinga ndi zimene zimatchedwa "kuganiza za ukhondo".

en: "The hygiene hypothesis is actually quite controversial because it's thought that our exposure to microbes isn't the only factor," says Cody Warren, a virologist and immunologist who is a postdoctoral fellow at the University of Colorado Boulder.
ny: "Lingaliro la ukhondo nlosatsutsika kwenikweni chifukwa chakuti limaonedwa kuti kusagwirizana kwathu ndi tizilombo toyambitsa matenda sikuli kokha", akutero Cody Warren, katswiri wa matenda a tizilombo ndi chitetezo cha m'thupi amene ali wophunzira pambuyo pa maphunziro a dotolo pa University of Colorado Boulder.

en: "A lot of this could also be dictated by genetics, diet, and the environment that we live in.
ny: "Zambiri za zimenezi zingathenso kulamulidwa ndi majini, zakudya, ndi malo amene tikukhala.

en: That also shapes our immune system… it's a real multifactorial thing that we can't fully account for just by wearing masks.
ny: Chimenecho chimapangitsanso chitetezo chathu cha m'thupi... ndi chinthu chenicheni cha zinthu zambiri chimene sitingathe kuchizindikira mwa kuvala masks.

en: There are other things that go into that equation."
ny: Pali zinthu zina zimene zimaloŵetsedwamo m'chiŵerengerocho".

en: Warren, the father of three young children, says spending lots of time outdoors is one way to balance the negatives of isolation.
ny: Warren, yemwe ali ndi ana atatu, ananena kuti kukhala panja nthawi yaitali ndi njira imodzi imene angapewere mavuto amene amabwera chifukwa chokhala payekha.

en: "Just exploring microbes in the environment also is benefiting [and] training our immune system," Warren says. "Our immune systems get trained through the foods that we eat, which also have microorganisms on them.
ny: "Kufunafuna tizilombo ting'onoting'ono m'chilengedwe kumapindulitsanso [ndi] kuphunzitsa chitetezo chathu cha m'thupi", akutero Warren. "Mphamvu zathu za m'thupi zimaphunzitsidwa ndi zakudya zimene timadya, zimene zimakhalanso ndi tizilombo ting'onoting'ono.

en: And so, despite the fact that we've kind of been hunkered down a little bit, I do feel that our immune systems will catch up."
ny: Ndipo chotero, ngakhale kuti takhala tikugwidwa pansi pang'ono, ndimamva kuti chitetezo chathu cha m'thupi chidzatenga nthaŵi".

en: There are other things parents can do, he says, to boost their childrens immune systems during pandemic times.  "One of the most important things you can do is just to stay up to date on vaccines.
ny: Iye anati pali zinthu zina zimene makolo angachite kuti alimbikitse chitetezo cha m'thupi cha ana awo panthawi ya mliriwu. "Chimodzi mwa zinthu zofunika kwambiri chimene mungachite ndicho kungodziwa bwino katemera.

en: That's one of the best ways that we have to train our immune systems," Warren says.
ny: Imeneyi ndi njira yabwino kwambiri yophunzitsira chitetezo chathu cha m'thupi", akutero Warren.

en: "But also, equally important is making sure our children have a good diet and they regulate stress.
ny: "Koma, chofunikanso kwambiri n'chakuti ana athu azidya zakudya zabwino ndiponso azichepetsa kupsinjika maganizo.

en: It's been well documented that both of those — having a good diet, a less stressful environment — can have a positive impact on our immune system."
ny: Zatsimikiziridwa bwino kuti zinthu zonsezi  kudya zakudya zabwino, kukhala m'malo opanda nkhawa  zingakhudze kwambiri chitetezo chathu cha m'thupi".

en: Once public health officials say masks are no longer necessary, Sawyer thinks pointing out the positives of putting our masks away could reassure hesitant parents who worry about their children getting sick.
ny: Akuluakulu a zaumoyo atati masks salinso ofunika, Sawyer akuganiza kuti kusonyeza ubwino wa kuika masks athu kutali kungatsimikizire makolo okayikakayika amene akuda nkhaŵa kuti ana awo angadwale.

en: "Maybe we should have a public conversation about the possible reasons to take that mask off, if they are in school, and get back to the normal repertoire of relatively safe childhood illnesses," she says.
ny: Iye anati: "Mwina tingachite bwino kukambirana ndi anthu onse kuti adziwe zifukwa zimene zingachititse kuti achotse chigobacho, ngati ali kusukulu, n'kubwerera ku matenda amene anawo amadwala omwe ndi otetezeka".

en: "The plus side of childhood illnesses is that they can build up that hornet's nest of immunity that could protect kids against new things that then come along."
ny: "Chimene chimapindulitsa kwambiri ndi matenda a ana n'chakuti amatha kulimbikitsa chitetezo cha m'thupi cha mpheta, chomwe chingawateteze ku matenda atsopano amene angabuke".

en: US Quietly Expands Asylum Limits While Preparing to End Them
ny: US Ikukulitsa Mzere wa Asylum Pamene Ikukonzekera Kuwuletsa

en: The Biden administration has begun expelling Cubans and Nicaraguans to Mexico under pandemic-related powers to deny migrants a chance to seek asylum, expanding use of the rule even as it publicly says it has been trying to unwind it, officials said Wednesday.
ny: Boma la Biden layamba kuthamangitsa anthu a ku Cuba ndi Nicaragua ku Mexico pansi pa mphamvu zokhudzana ndi mliriwu kuti alepheretse anthu osamukira kudziko lina kuti apeze chitetezo, kukulitsa kugwiritsa ntchito lamuloli ngakhale kuti linanena poyera kuti lakhala likuyesera kuti lisathetsedwe, akuluakulu adati Lachitatu.

en: The U.S. struck agreement with Mexico to expel up to 100 Cubans and 20 Nicaraguans a day from three locations: San Diego; El Paso, Texas; and Rio Grande Valley, Texas, according to a U.S. official with direct knowledge of the effort.
ny: Malinga ndi kunena kwa mkulu wa boma la United States wodziŵa bwino za ntchitoyi, dziko la Mexico linagwirizana ndi United States kuti lizitulutsa anthu 100 a ku Cuba ndi 20 a ku Nicaragua tsiku lililonse m'malo atatu: San Diego; El Paso, Texas; ndi Rio Grande Valley, Texas.

en: The expulsions began April 27 and will end May 22, the official told The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the agreement has not been made public.
ny: Kuchotsedwa kwa anthu kunayamba pa April 27 ndipo kudzatha pa May 22, mkuluyu anauza Associated Press pa lamulo la kusadziwika chifukwa chakuti mgwirizanowo sunaperekedwe poyera.

en: They are carried out under Title 42 authority, a public health law that has been used to expel migrants on grounds of preventing spread of COVID-19. Title 42 is due to expire May 23, unless a judge intervenes.
ny: Iwo akuchitidwa pansi pa ulamuliro wa mutu wa 42, lamulo la zaumoyo wa anthu lomwe lagwiritsidwa ntchito kuthamangitsa anthu othawa kwawo chifukwa choletsa kufalikira kwa COVID-19. Mutu wa 42 udzatha pa 23 May, pokhapokha woweruza atalowerera.

en: The U.S. and Mexico agreed April 26 to a very limited number of expulsions of Cubans and Nicaraguans, according to a high-level Mexican official who spoke on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to comment publicly.
ny: United States ndi Mexico zinagwirizana pa April 26 kuti anthu ochepa okha a ku Cuba ndi Nicaragua athamangitsidwe, malinga ndi mkulu wina wa boma wa ku Mexico amene analankhula mosatchula dzina lake chifukwa sanavomerezedwe kuti afotokoze poyera.

en: It was prompted by higher numbers of migrants from those two countries coming to the U.S. border.
ny: Zimenezi zinachitika chifukwa cha kuchuluka kwa anthu ochokera m'mayiko awiriwa amene anafika m'malire a dziko la United States.

en: Mexico also took into account that the U.S. government had started processing visas in Cuba again, the official said. Mexico had also begun processing visas for Cubans.
ny: Mexico inaganiziranso kuti boma la United States layambanso kukonza ma visa ku Cuba, anatero mkuluyo. Mexico inayambanso kukonza ma visa a anthu a ku Cuba.

en: Another Mexican official, also not authorized to comment publicly, confirmed that up to 100 Cubans and 20 Nicaraguans were being expelled from San Diego under Title 42.
ny: Mkulu wina wa boma la Mexico, yemwenso sanavomerezedwe kunenapo kanthu poyera, anatsimikizira kuti anthu 100 a ku Cuba ndi 20 a ku Nicaragua anali kuthamangitsidwa ku San Diego pansi pa Mutu 42.

en: The U.S. Department of Homeland Security did not immediately respond to a request for comment.
ny: Dipatimenti ya U.S. ya za Chitetezo cha Dziko Lapansi sinayankhe nthaŵi yomweyo pempho la ndemanga.

en: Until last week, Mexico only agreed to take Guatemalans, Hondurans and El Salvadorans — in addition to Mexicans — under Title 42 authority. Other nationalities are subject to Title 42 but costs, strained diplomatic ties and other considerations often make it difficult to send them back to their home countries.
ny: Mpaka sabata yatha, Mexico inalola kulandira anthu a ku Guatemala, Honduras ndi El Salvador  kuwonjezera pa anthu a ku Mexico  pansi pa ulamuliro wa Mutu 42. Mitundu ina imakhudzidwa ndi Mutu 42 koma ndalama, ubale wa diplomatic ndi zina zambiri zimachititsa kuti zikhale zovuta kuwatumiza kwawo.

en: It's next to impossible for the U.S. to expel migrants to Cuba or Nicaragua because of poor relations with those governments. That has posed a challenge for the Biden administration as more people from those countries seek haven in the United States.
ny: Ndizosatheka kuti dziko la US lipititse anthu osamukira ku Cuba kapena ku Nicaragua chifukwa cha ubale woipa ndi maboma amenewo. Izi zakhala zovuta kwa boma la Biden pamene anthu ambiri ochokera m'maiko amenewo akufunafuna chitetezo ku United States.

en: Cubans were stopped by U.S. authorities more than 32,000 times on the Mexican border in March, double the number in February and more than five times October's count, according to U.S. Customs and Border Protection. Nicaragua eased travel restrictions from Cuba in November, making it easier for Cubans to continue by land to the U.S. border. Most enter the U.S. in or near Yuma, Arizona, and Del Rio, Texas.
ny: Anthu a ku Cuba anaimitsidwa ndi akuluakulu a boma la United States maulendo oposa 32,000 pamalire a Mexico mu March, kuwirikiza kawiri chiwerengerochi mu February ndi kuwirikiza kasanu chiŵerengero cha mu October, malinga ndi US Customs and Border Protection. Nicaragua inachepetsa zoletsa kuyenda kuchokera ku Cuba mu November, zomwe zinapangitsa kuti zikhale zosavuta kwa anthu a ku Cuba kuti apitirize ulendo wawo wa pamtunda kupita kumalire a United States. Ambiri amalowa ku United States mu Yuma, Arizona, ndi Del Rio, Texas.

en: Nicaraguans were stopped more than 16,000 times in March, more than double September's level. The vast majority enter in South Texas.
ny: Anthu a ku Nicaragua anaimitsidwa maulendo oposa 16,000 mu March, kuposa kawiri kuposa mmene zinalili mu September.

en: Lifting Title 42 has proved controversial as midterm elections near, even for Biden's Democratic Party, amid concerns that the U.S. is unprepared for an anticipated increase in migrants seeking asylum. Authorities stopped migrants more than 221,000 times in March, the highest mark in 22 years.
ny: Kuchotsa mutu wa 42 kwachititsa kuti pakhale mikangano chifukwa cha chisankho cha pakati pa nyengo, ngakhale chipani cha Democratic cha Biden, pakati pa nkhawa zoti dziko la US silinakonzekere kuwonjezeka kwa anthu othawa kwawo. Akuluakulu a boma analetsa anthu othawa kwawo maulendo oposa 221,000 mu March, chiwerengero chapamwamba kwambiri m'zaka 22.

en: The White House and Homeland Security Department have publicly stood behind the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's decision to end the measure because it could no longer be justified on grounds of protecting public health.
ny: Nyumba ya White ndi Dipatimenti ya Chitetezo cha M'dziko (DHS) zathandiza poyera pa chigamulo cha Centers for Disease Control and Prevention choletsa lamuloli chifukwa silingachititsidwenso kukhala loyenera chifukwa cha kuteteza thanzi la anthu.

en: But the practice of expelling Cubans and Nicaraguans runs counter to the administration's public statements that it was phasing out use of the pandemic powers to prepare for May 23.
ny: Koma chizolowezi chochotsa anthu a ku Cuba ndi Nicaragua chimatsutsana ndi mawu a boma akuti akuchotsa kugwiritsa ntchito mphamvu za mliri kuti akonzekere Meyi 23.

en: The U.S. has expelled migrants more than 1.8 million times under Title 42 authority since March 2020, effectively overriding rights to seek asylum under U.S. law and international treaty. In doing so, migrants are not subject to immigration law, which include rights to seek protection from persecution at home.
ny: United States yatulutsa anthu osamukira m'dziko lawo maulendo opitirira 1.8 miliyoni pansi pa lamulo la mutu 42 kuyambira mu March 2020, zomwe zikuchotsa ufulu wofunafuna chitetezo pansi pa malamulo a United States ndi mgwirizano wa mayiko.

en: The administration said in court filings that it began processing more Central American adults under immigration laws after the CDC's announcement on April 1. But a federal judge in Louisiana ruled last week that it couldn't start unwinding Title 42 while it was still in effect.
ny: Boma linanena m'malamulo a khoti kuti linayamba kusamalira anthu akuluakulu a ku Central America pansi pa malamulo a kusamukira ku mayiko ena pambuyo pa kulengeza kwa CDC pa April 1. Koma woweruza wa boma ku Louisiana anagamula sabata yatha kuti silingathe kuyamba kuchotsa Mutu 42 pamene unali ukadali m'chigamulo.

en: U.S. District Judge Robert Summerhays strongly criticized the CDC's decision, suggesting he would try to keep Title 42 in effect after May 23. A hearing is scheduled May 13 for oral arguments.
ny: Woweruza wa chigawo cha United States Robert Summerhays anatsutsa kwambiri chigamulo cha CDC, akumanena kuti ayesa kusunga Mutu 42 wogwira ntchito pambuyo pa May 23. Kumvetsera kwa May 13 kwaikidwa kuti kukambirane.

en: Marisa Limon, senior director of advocacy and planning at the Hope Border Institute, said advocates began learning about expulsions of Cubans and Nicaraguans from El Paso on Monday and later confirmed the new practice with U.S. officials.
ny: Marisa Limon, mkulu wa bungwe loona za ufulu wa anthu ndi kukonzekera pa Hope Border Institute, anati anthu olimbikitsa ufulu wa anthu anayamba kuphunzira za kuthamangitsidwa kwa anthu a ku Cuba ndi Nicaragua ku El Paso Lolemba ndipo pambuyo pake anatsimikizira kuti zimenezi zachitika ndi akuluakulu a ku United States.

en: Limon said the administration is "trying to get every last bit out of Title 42" before it expires. She called it "sobering" but consistent with the administration's efforts to have other countries in the Western hemisphere take more responsibility for hosting people fleeing their homes.
ny: Limon anati boma "likuyesa kupeza mbali yonse ya Mutu 42" lisanathe. Iye anautcha kuti "kudzikonda" koma mogwirizana ndi zoyesayesa za boma kuti mayiko ena a kumadzulo kwa dziko lapansi atenge udindo waukulu wolandira anthu othawa kwawo.

en: Mexico Relocates Migrant Camp; Haitians Appear at Border
ny: Dziko la Mexico Limasamutsa Msasa wa Anthu Othawa kwawo; Anthu a ku Haiti Akuoneka pa Malire

en: Mexican authorities said Tuesday they have relocated a migrant camp that sprung up in a park in the border city of Reynosa, moving about 2,000 people from Central America and Haiti to a shelter in the city, across the border from McAllen, Texas.
ny: Akuluakulu a ku Mexico anena Lachiwiri kuti asamutsa msasa wa anthu othawa kwawo womwe unabuka m'paki mumzinda wa Reynosa, womwe uli m'malire ndi dziko la Mexico, ndipo anthu pafupifupi 2,000 ochokera ku Central America ndi ku Haiti asamukira kumalo othawirako anthu mumzindawu, womwe uli m'malire ndi McAllen, ku Texas.

en: The camp of migrants mainly from Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras and Haiti sprung up after U.S. officials, citing the pandemic, invoked a health rule that denies migrants a chance to seek asylum.
ny: Msasa wa anthu othawa kwawo makamaka ochokera ku Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras ndi Haiti unabuka pambuyo poti akuluakulu a ku United States, potchula za mliriwu, agwiritsa ntchito lamulo la zaumoyo lomwe limaletsa anthu othawa kwawo kuti asapeze mwayi wopempha chitetezo.

en: Mexico's National Immigration Institute said the migrants were taken around midnight Monday to the shelter, which it said will have better hygiene and food services.
ny: Bungwe la National Immigration Institute la ku Mexico linanena kuti anthuwa anapita nawo kumalo osungirako anthu othawa kwawowo, komwe akuti adzakhala ndi ukhondo wabwino komanso chakudya.

en: But on Monday, people in another border city, Nuevo Laredo, said hundreds of migrants, mainly Haitians, have streamed into that city, which is across the border from Laredo, Texas
ny: Koma Lolemba, anthu a mumzinda wina wapafupi ndi malire, Nuevo Laredo, anati anthu mazana ambiri, makamaka a ku Haiti, analowa mumzinda umenewo, womwe uli kutsidya lina la malire a Laredo, Texas.

en: The rush apparently started after the U.S. began processing some asylum-seekers there.
ny: Zikuoneka kuti anthu anayamba kukakamizidwa kutero pambuyo poti dziko la United States layamba kusamalira anthu ena ofuna kuthawira m'dzikoli.

en: The Catholic bishop of Nuevo Laredo said Monday that migrant shelters there are overcrowded, with some migrants sleeping outside in tents.
ny: Bishopu wa Katolika wa ku Nuevo Laredo ananena Lolemba kuti malo osungirako anthu othaŵa kwawo ali odzaza kwambiri, ndipo anthu ena othaŵa kwawo akugona kunja m'mahema.

en: Bishop Enrique Sánchez Martínez said migrants started streaming into Nuevo Laredo in late April, though the city isn't usually popular among migrants, in part because it is dominated by the violent Northeast drug cartel.
ny: Bishopu Enrique Sánchez Martínez anati anthu othawa kwawo anayamba kulowa m'tauni ya Nuevo Laredo kumapeto kwa mwezi wa April, ngakhale kuti mzindawu si wotchuka kwambiri kwa anthu othawa kwawo, makamaka chifukwa chakuti uli ndi gulu la zigawenga za mankhwala osokoneza bongo la kumpoto chakum'mawa.

en: "It is new for us because this is the last place they come, due to the conditions of our border, of our city, which are sometimes adverse for migrants," the bishop said. "But since they opened the door in the United States to asylum requests, a lot of them came in large groups."
ny: "Ndi chatsopano kwa ife chifukwa ndi malo omalizira amene amabwera, chifukwa cha mikhalidwe ya malire athu, ya mzinda wathu, yomwe nthaŵi zina imakhala yopweteka kwa osamuka", anatero bishopuyo. "Koma popeza anatsegula chitseko ku United States kwa opempha chipulumutso, ambiri a iwo anabwera m'magulu akuluakulu".

en: Marvin Ajic, the director of the Casa Nazareth shelter, said that around April 16, Mexican authorities notified the shelters that the United States would resume processing asylum claims for humanitarian reasons.
ny: Marvin Ajic, mkulu wa nyumba yotetezera anthu ya Casa Nazareth, ananena kuti cha m'ma April 16, akuluakulu a boma la Mexico anawadziwitsa nyumba zotetezera anthu kuti United States iyambiranso kukonza mapempho a anthu othaŵa kwawo chifukwa cha zifukwa zaumunthu.

en: The U.S. had begun allowing more people in, especially Central American adults, to prepare for lifting Title 42 — a pandemic-era health rule that denies migrants a chance to enter the U.S. seek asylum — on May 23. But a federal judge in Louisiana ruled last week that the government could not unwind the rule before the end date.
ny: Dziko la United States linayamba kulola anthu ambiri kulowa, makamaka achikulire a ku Central America, kukonzekera kuchotsa lamulo la mutu 42  lamulo la zaumoyo la m'nthawi ya mliriwu lomwe limaletsa anthu osamukira ku United States kuti afunefune chitetezo  pa 23 May. Koma woweruza wa boma ku Louisiana analamula sabata yatha kuti boma silingathe kuchotsa lamuloli lisanafike tsiku lomaliza.

en: "The (Mexican) immigration officials organized things with the shelters, and the plan was to send people who had been waiting a long time, without any checks, basically anyone," Ajic said.
ny: "Akuluakulu a boma la (Mexico) la anthu olowa m'dziko anakonza zinthu ndi malo ogona, ndipo cholinga chinali kutumiza anthu amene anali kudikira kwa nthaŵi yaitali, popanda kufufuza, kwenikweni aliyense", anatero Ajic.

en: That apparently drew the attention of other migrants, including Haitians.
ny: Zikuoneka kuti zimenezi zinakopa chidwi cha anthu ena amene anasamukira ku Haiti, kuphatikizapo anthu a ku Haiti.

en: In September, similar rumors sparked a rush by about 15,000 mostly Haitian refugees to the Texas border, where they camped under a bridge. U.S. officials began large scale deportations of Haitians while also allowing thousands to remain in the U.S.
ny: Mu September, mphekesera zofananazo zinayambitsa kuthamangira kwa othaŵa kwawo pafupifupi 15,000, ambiri a iwo achi Haiti, kumka kumalire a Texas, kumene anamanga misasa pansi pa mlatho. Akuluakulu a ku United States anayamba kuthamangitsa anthu ambiri a ku Haiti pamene analola kuti zikwizikwi zikhalebe ku United States.

en: Ajic warned migrants against coming to the border, noting the risks. On Monday, Mexico's National Immigration Institute said that so far this year, it has pulled the bodies of 19 immigrants from the Rio Grande, also known as the Rio Bravo.
ny: Ajic anachenjeza anthu othawa kwawo kuti asamayende m'malire, pofotokoza za kuopsa kwake. Lolemba, bungwe la National Immigration Institute la ku Mexico linanena kuti chaka chino, latulutsa mitembo ya anthu 19 othawa kwawo m'mphepete mwa mtsinje wa Rio Grande, womwe umadziwikanso kuti Rio Bravo.

en: New US Rule Grants Automatic Work Permit Extensions to Noncitizens
ny: Lamulo Latsopano la US Limapereka Ntchito Zodziwikiratu Limalolanso Kupititsa Anthu Osakhala Nzika

en: U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) announced Tuesday that it would automatically extend for 360 days the work permits of immigrants who applied to renew their work authorization amid the current backlog in processing times.
ny: Bungwe la U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) linalengeza Lachiwiri kuti lidzakulitsa masiku 360 a chilolezo cha ntchito cha anthu olowa m'dziko lawo amene anapempha kuti akhazikitsenso chilolezo chawo cha ntchito pakati pa nthawi imene anthuwo akuchedwa kukonzekera ntchito.

en: The new notice expands on the 180-day extension USCIS announced in November. It is expected to prevent about 260,000 immigrants from losing their work permits in the next 18 months. It will also give the agency extra time to clear applicants waiting in line, the agency said in a statement.
ny: Chidziwitso chatsopanochi chikuwonjezera masiku 180 omwe USCIS idalengeza mu Novembala. Zikuyembekezeka kuteteza anthu osamuka pafupifupi 260,000 kuti asataye zilolezo zawo zogwirira ntchito m'miyezi 18 ikubwerayi. Zidzapatsanso bungwe nthawi yowonjezera kuti lipewe ofunsira omwe akudikirira pamzere, bungwe lidanena m'mawu.

en: "This temporary rule will provide those noncitizens otherwise eligible for the automatic extension an opportunity to maintain employment and provide critical support for their families while avoiding further disruption for U.S. employers," USCIS Director Ur M. Jaddou said in a statement.
ny: "Lamulo la kanthaŵi kochepa limeneli lidzapereka mwayi kwa anthu amene sali nzika za dziko limene lingathe kupatsidwa mwayi wowonjezera ntchito ndi kupereka thandizo lofunika kwambiri kwa mabanja awo pamene akupewa kusokoneza mabwana a ku United States", anatero mkulu wa USCIS, Ur M. Jaddou m'mawu ake.

en: The extension, which takes effect Wednesday, aims to stabilize operations for U.S. employers and help people with pending employment authorizations who have a job and are working in the U.S.
ny: Kuonjezera, kumene kumayamba kugwira ntchito Lachitatu, cholinga chake ndicho kukhazikitsa ntchito za mabwana a ku United States ndi kuthandiza anthu omwe ali ndi chilolezo choyembekezera ntchito omwe ali ndi ntchito ndipo akugwira ntchito ku United States.

en: USCIS is the agency in charge of handling the nation's immigration paperwork. In recent years, it has struggled with backlogs, an issue made worse by the COVID-19 pandemic and budget shortfalls.
ny: USCIS ndi bungwe lomwe limayang'anira ntchito za anthu olowa m'dziko. M'zaka zaposachedwapa, lakhala likulimbana ndi mavuto a kusowa kwa ndalama, vuto lomwe lawonjezeka chifukwa cha mliri wa COVID-19 komanso kusowa kwa bajeti.

en: In April, Jaddou told U.S. government officials during a congressional hearing that USCIS had 8.5 million pending immigration cases, including those seeking green cards and U.S. naturalization.
ny: Mu April, Jaddou anauza akuluakulu a boma la United States pa msonkhano wa m'bungwe la Congress kuti USCIS inali ndi milandu yokwana 8.5 miliyoni yoyembekezera kuloŵa m'dziko, kuphatikizapo anthu ofuna kupeza makadi obiriwira ndi kuloŵa m'dziko la United States.

en: She said more than half of those pending cases were taking longer than the agency's normal processing times.
ny: Iye anati zoposa theka la milandu imene inali itatsirizika inali kutenga nthaŵi yaitali kuposa nthaŵi imene bungwe limathera pofufuza milandu.

en: Asylum-seekers, immigrants adjusting their status to permanent residence and other noncitizens going through the U.S. immigration process are among the noncitizens affected by the latest work authorization extension.
ny: Anthu ofuna kuthawira m'dziko lina, anthu osamuka kumene amene akufuna kukhala ndi malo okhazikika okhala, ndi anthu ena omwe si nzika za dziko lina amene akukhala m'dziko la United States ali m'gulu la anthu amene sanaloledwe kukhala nzika za dziko lina chifukwa cha ntchito imene anawonjezera posachedwapa.

en: The agency had reported that processing times for asylum applicants looking to renew work permits increased from seven months in 2017 to 11 months in 2021.
ny: Bungweli linati nthawi yochitira zinthu ndi anthu ofuna kuthawa kwawo amene akufuna kukonzanso chilolezo cha ntchito inakula kuchoka pa miyezi 7 mu 2017 kufika pa miyezi 11 mu 2021.

en: In March, USCIS announced a program to reduce backlogs, including the expansion of premium processing for certain applications where applicants could pay a higher fee to expedite paperwork processing.
ny: Mu March, USCIS inalengeza pulogalamu yochepetsera kusowa kwa zinthu, kuphatikizapo kuwonjezeka kwa ntchito zolipirira ntchito zina pamene ofunsira angapereke ndalama zambiri kuti afulumizitse ntchito yolemba mapepala.

en: According to the USCIS, most of the announced changes simply restore options offered before the Trump administration's slowdown of USCIS processing and before the COVID-19 pandemic further slowed the agency's resources.
ny: Malinga ndi USCIS, kusintha kwakukulu kumene kunalengezedwa kumangobwezeretsa njira zomwe zinaperekedwa boma la Trump lisanayambe kuchepetsa ntchito za USCIS komanso mliri wa COVID-19 usanachepetse kwambiri ntchito za bungwe.

en: "For several years, USCIS has been in a precarious financial situation that has impaired the efficient completion of caseloads. The COVID-19 pandemic exacerbated these challenges in 2020, in addition to a hiring freeze and furlough threat leading to workforce attrition and severely reduced capacity. In 2021, before USCIS could recover from these fiscal and operational impacts, there was a sudden and dramatic increase in EAD (Employment Authorization Document) initial and renewal filings," according to the USCIS statement.
ny: "Kwa zaka zingapo, USCIS yakhala ili pamavuto azachuma omwe adasokoneza kumaliza bwino milandu. Mliri wa COVID-19 udakulitsa zovuta izi mu 2020, kuphatikiza pakuwopseza kuletsa ntchito ndi kuthawa komwe kumapangitsa kuti anthu azigwira ntchito komanso kuchepa kwakukulu. Mu 2021, USCIS isanachire ku zovuta izi zachuma ndi magwiridwe antchito, panali kuwonjezeka kwadzidzidzi komanso kwakukulu kwa EAD (Employment Authorization Document) ndi zolembetsa zoyambirira, "malinga ndi zomwe USCIS idatero.

en: The USCIS historically has been underfunded because most of the agency's funding comes from application fees that have stalled at $5 billion a year since 2019.
ny: M'mbuyomu, bungwe la USCIS linalibe ndalama zokwanira chifukwa ndalama zambiri za bungweli zimachokera ku ndalama zolipirira ntchito zomwe zakhala zikukwera pa $ 5 biliyoni pachaka kuyambira 2019.

en: What Is the US-Launched 'Uniting for Ukraine' Program?
ny: Kodi Pulogalamu ya 'Kugwirizana kwa Ukraine' Yoyambitsidwa ndi United States N'chiyani?

en: U.S. President Joe Biden recently announced the Uniting for Ukraine program, which aims to streamline the process for Ukrainians who have fled their country and are seeking safety in the United States.
ny: Pulezidenti wa United States Joe Biden posachedwapa analengeza za pulogalamu ya Uniting for Ukraine, yomwe cholinga chake ndi kuchepetsa mavuto a anthu a ku Ukraine amene anathawa m'dziko lawo ndipo akufunafuna chitetezo ku United States.

en: The new program, which took effect Monday, will complement existing legal pathways available to those fleeing Russian aggression due to the ongoing Russia-Ukraine crisis, Biden administration officials said.
ny: Pulogalamu yatsopanoyi, yomwe idayamba kugwira ntchito Lolemba, idzawonjezera njira zalamulo zomwe zilipo kale kwa iwo omwe akuthawa chiwawa cha Russia chifukwa cha mavuto omwe akuchitika pakati pa Russia ndi Ukraine, atero akuluakulu aboma la Biden.

en: "The U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) will continue to provide relief to the Ukrainian people, while supporting our European allies who have shouldered so much as the result of Russia's brutal invasion of Ukraine," Secretary of Homeland Security Alejandro Mayorkas said in a statement to reporters on April 21.
ny: "Unduna wa Zachitetezo cha M'dziko la United States (DHS) upitiriza kupereka chithandizo kwa anthu a ku Ukraine, pamene ukuchirikiza anzathu a ku Ulaya amene avutika kwambiri chifukwa cha kuphulitsa nkhanza kwa Russia ku Ukraine", anatero Secretary of Homeland Security Alejandro Mayorkas m'mawu ake kwa atolankhani pa April 21.

en: What is Uniting for Ukraine?
ny: Kodi Kugwirizana kwa Ukraine N'kutani?

en: The program allows U.S. citizens and residents to sponsor Ukrainian refugees under different immigration statuses. The online portal, open to potential sponsors or organizations, is accepting applications and has received more than 4,000 requests so far, CNN reported.
ny: Pulogalamuyi imalola nzika za ku America ndi anthu okhala m'dzikolo kuti azipereka ndalama kwa anthu othawa kwawo ku Ukraine omwe ali ndi udindo wosiyana ndi awo.

en: Who qualifies under the program?  Ukrainians, or an immediate family member of a Ukrainian citizen. They must have a U.S. sponsor and have been a resident of Ukraine as of February 11.
ny: Amene ali oyenerera m'dongosolo limeneli ndi a ku Ukraine kapena achibale a nzika ya ku Ukraine. Ayenera kukhala ndi munthu wowathandiza ku United States ndipo ayenera kukhala ku Ukraine kuyambira pa February 11.

en: What are the requirements?   They must pass security checks — including a fingerprint and an FBI name check and biographic and biometric screening — and meet public health requirements, such as having the proper vaccinations, before entering the U.S.
ny: Kodi ndi zinthu ziti zimene akufunikira? Ayenera kukwanitsa mayeso a chitetezo  kuphatikizapo kuika zala zawo m'manja ndi kufufuza dzina la munthu ndi dzina la FBI ndi kufufuza mbiri ya munthu ndi kayendedwe ka thupi  ndiponso kukwaniritsa zofunikira zaumoyo wa anthu, monga kukhala ndi katemera woyenera, asanapite ku United States

en: Those approved will be allowed to travel to the U.S., be considered for humanitarian parole on a case-by-case basis, stay in the country for two years, and apply for work permits.
ny: Amene avomerezedwa adzaloledwa kupita ku United States, ndipo adzapatsidwa chilolezo cha kuloledwa kuloŵa m'dzikoli, ndipo adzapatsidwa chilolezo chokhala m'dzikolo kwa zaka ziwiri.

en: "The United States strongly encourages Ukrainians seeking refuge in the United States who do not have and are not eligible for a visa to seek entry via Uniting for Ukraine from Europe. This will be the safest and most efficient way to pursue temporary refuge in the United States," a DHS statement said.
ny: "United States ikulimbikitsa kwambiri anthu a ku Ukraine ofunafuna chitetezo ku United States omwe alibe ndipo sangakwanitse kupeza visa kuti afunefune kulowa kudzera mu United for Ukraine kuchokera ku Ulaya. Iyi idzakhala njira yotetezeka komanso yothandiza kwambiri kuti apeze chitetezo chokhalitsa ku United States", adatero a DHS.

en: Who qualifies as a sponsor?
ny: Kodi ndani amene ali woyenera kukhala wothandizira?

en: U.S. citizens and other residents who hold lawful status in the United States or who are beneficiaries of Deferred Enforced Departure, Temporary Protected Status, or Deferred Action, among others.
ny: Nzika za ku United States ndi anthu ena okhala ku United States omwe ali ndi ufulu wochoka m'dzikolo kapena amene ali ndi ufulu wotetezedwa kwakanthawi, kapena wotetezedwa kwakanthawi, kapena wotetezedwa kwa kanthawi.

en: Sponsors will be required to prove they can financially support the refugee while they are in the U.S. They also need to pass security and background vetting "to protect against exploitation and abuse." The Ukrainian applicant will receive authorization only after everything is verified, including that the sponsor has the means to support them while they are in the U.S.
ny: Anthu amene amapereka ndalamazo ayenera kutsimikizira kuti angathe kuthandiza munthu wothawa kwawoyo pa nthawi imene ali ku United States. Komanso ayenera kuchita kafukufuku wa zachitetezo ndi za mbiri ya munthu wothawa kwawoyo "kuti atetezedwe kuti asagwiritsidwe ntchito molakwa". Munthu amene akufuna kulowa dziko la Ukraine adzapatsidwa chilolezo chokha pokhapokha zinthu zonse zitatsimikiziridwa, kuphatikizapo kuti munthu amene amapereka ndalamazo ali ndi ndalama zoti azitha kumuthandiza pa nthawi imene ali ku United States.

en: Who is not eligible for parole under the program?
ny: Kodi ndani amene sangapatsidwe ufulu wa kusamutsidwa malinga ndi pulogalamuyi?

en: Ukrainian citizens already in the U.S. are not eligible for parole under Uniting for Ukraine.
ny: Nzika za ku Ukraine zomwe zili kale ku United States sizingaloledwe kuloledwa kuloŵa m'ndende malinga ndi malamulo a bungwe la Uniting for Ukraine.

en: However, they can apply for Temporary Protected Status, which is another form of humanitarian relief that allows people to legally stay and work in the U.S.
ny: Komabe, iwo angapemphe kuti apeze Chitetezo cha Nthaŵi Yochepa, chimene chili mtundu wina wa chithandizo chaumunthu chimene chimalola anthu kukhala ndi kugwira ntchito m'dziko la United States mwalamulo.

en: What about those arriving at the U.S.-Mexico border?
ny: Nanga bwanji za anthu amene amafika kumalire a dziko la United States ndi Mexico?

en: Citing safety issues, U.S. officials have urged Ukrainians not to travel to Mexico in hopes of entering the United States. In addition, U.S. Customs and Border Protection has no place to hold them while they go through the Uniting for Ukraine vetting process.
ny: Chifukwa cha nkhani zachitetezo, akuluakulu a boma la United States apempha anthu a ku Ukraine kuti asapite ku Mexico ndi cholinga choti alowe m'dziko la United States.

en: Since Uniting for Ukraine's launch on Monday, Ukrainians who arrive at U.S. ports of entry without a valid visa or without preauthorization to travel to the United States through the Uniting for Ukraine program will be denied entry and told to apply to the program.
ny: Chiyambireni kukhazikitsidwa kwa ntchito ya Uniting for Ukraine Lolemba, anthu a ku Ukraine amene afika ku US popanda visa kapena chilolezo chopita ku United States kudzera mu pulogalamu ya Uniting for Ukraine, sadzaloledwa kulowa m'dzikolo ndipo adzauzidwa kuti apemphe nawo ntchitoyi.

en: Biden officials hope this will curb the number of Ukrainian migrants seeking humanitarian parole along the border.
ny: Akuluakulu a Biden akuyembekeza kuti izi zidzachepetsa chiwerengero cha anthu othawa kwawo ku Ukraine ofuna kuti apatsidwe ufulu wa anthu kumayiko ena.

en: Those at the border must apply under the rules of Uniting for Ukraine, meaning they must have a qualifying sponsor or a non-government agency willing to sponsor them in the U.S. for up to two years. And they need to have all required vaccinations and pass background checks.
ny: Anthu amene ali kumalire ayenera kulembetsa malinga ndi malamulo a bungwe la Uniting for Ukraine, kutanthauza kuti ayenera kukhala ndi munthu wowapatsa ndalama kapena bungwe la boma lomwe si la boma limene limafuna kuwapatsa ndalama kuti akhale ku United States kwa zaka ziwiri.

en: The Biden administration announced the private sponsorship initiative as another way the U.S. hopes to achieve President Biden's commitment to welcome up to 100,000 Ukrainians displaced by the Russian military invasion.
ny: Boma la Biden linalengeza za ntchito yolimbikitsa anthu payekha monga njira ina imene US ikuyembekezera kukwaniritsira lonjezo la Pulezidenti Biden lolandira anthu okwana 100,000 a ku Ukraine omwe anathawa kwawo chifukwa cha nkhondo ya Russia.

en: As of Thursday, almost 5.4 million refugees have since left Ukraine, according to U.N. data.
ny: Malinga ndi zimene bungwe la United Nations linanena, kuyambira Lachinayi, anthu pafupifupi 5.4 miliyoni omwe anathawa kwawo achoka ku Ukraine.

en: Report: Rwanda Should Ease Restrictions On 2003 National Elections - 2001-10-15
ny: Lipoti: Rwanda Iyenera Kuchepetsa Kuletsa pa Zisankho za 2003 - 2001-10-15

en: In 2003 Rwanda will hold its first national elections since the 1994 genocide. A new report says the government of Rwanda needs to relax its control over public life if the polls are to have any credibility.
ny: Mu 2003 Rwanda idzachita zisankho zake zoyamba za dziko lonse kuyambira pamene anthu anaphedwa mu 1994. Lipoti latsopano limanena kuti boma la Rwanda liyenera kuchepetsa kulamulira kwake pa moyo wa anthu ngati mavotiwo akufuna kukhala ndi chikhulupiliro.

en: There was relief when the Rwandan Patriotic Front seized power in Rwanda in 1994, ending the genocide in which about 800,000 minority Tutsis and moderate Hutus were killed.
ny: Panali mpumulo pamene Rwandan Patriotic Front inalanda ulamuliro mu Rwanda mu 1994, kuthetsa kupha anthu kumene kunapha anthu pafupifupi 800,000 a Tutsi ndi a Hutu ofatsa.

en: The new military government promised to restore democracy to Rwanda via elections in 2003.
ny: Boma latsopano la asilikali linalonjeza kuti lidzayambitsanso demokalase ku Rwanda kudzera m'zisankho mu 2003.

en: That process began in March this year, with district elections.
ny: Ntchito imeneyi inayamba mu March chaka chino, ndi zisankho za m'zigawo.

en: Senior analyst Francois Grignon, of the International Crisis Group, a Brussels-based policy research organization, says he was disappointed with the district poll. Mr. Grignon says the process was so tightly controlled that he maintains no genuine opposition candidates were allowed to stand.
ny: Katswiri wamkulu wa kafukufuku wa mayiko, Francois Grignon, wa bungwe la International Crisis Group, bungwe lofufuza za malamulo, lochokera ku Brussels, akuti anakhumudwa ndi chisankho cha chigawochi.

en: "There was a screening and there was a preparation of the elections, which did not allow other candidates than those who had been rubber-stamped by the government to actually contest, especially for the executive positions within the local authorities," he says. "If consensual democracy means that the political debate is actually handled before the electoral contest in such a way that it does not lead to a real competition then there is no democracy at all."
ny: "Panali kusanthula ndi kukonzekera zisankho, zomwe sizinalole ofuna ena kupatula omwe anali atatsimikiziridwa ndi boma kuti ayesetse, makamaka pa maudindo oyang'anira maboma", akutero. "Ngati demokalase yovomerezeka ikutanthauza kuti zokambirana zandale zimayendetsedwa musanayambe mpikisano wa zisankho m'njira yoti sizingayambitse mpikisano weniweni ndiye kuti palibe demokalase konse".

en: In a new report, titled Consensual Democracy in Post Genocide Rwanda, the International Crisis Group urges the international community to pressure Rwanda's government to liberalize political activity.
ny: Mu lipoti latsopano, lotchedwa Consensual Democracy in Post Genocide Rwanda, International Crisis Group ikulimbikitsa anthu a m'mayiko osiyanasiyana kuti aziumiriza boma la Rwanda kuti lipereke ufulu pa ndale.

en: The report notes that the military dominates public life and there is little open criticism of the government, either in the media or by opposition figures. The Rwanda government argues that allowing a range of opinions would be dangerous in a country struggling to come to terms with its bloody past.
ny: Lipotilo linati asilikali ndi amene amalamulira moyo wa anthu ndipo anthu ambiri samatsutsa boma, kaya ndi atolankhani kapena anthu otsutsa. Boma la Rwanda limanena kuti kulola maganizo osiyanasiyana kungakhale koopsa m'dziko limene likuvutika kuti livomereze zinthu zoipa zimene zinachitika m'mbuyomu.

en: But Mr. Grignon says dissent is simply being driven underground or outside Rwanda's borders.
ny: Koma Bambo Grignon akuti anthu amene sakugwirizana ndi mfundo za boma akungoyendetsedwa mobisa kapena kunja kwa malire a dziko la Rwanda.

en: "Opponents to the regime have to flee the country or to join in rebel movements outside the country or in the Congo and no chance to express a different view," he says. "All the good policies that the government has been implementing - including the organization of the elections, national elections, presidential and parliamentary, in 2003 - will lack the credibility because they were not implemented in an environment that actually allowed a fair contest to take place," he says.
ny: Iye anati: "Anthu amene amatsutsa boma la dziko la Congo amafunika kuthawa m'dzikolo kapena kulowa m'magulu a zigawenga kunja kwa dzikolo kapena m'dziko la Congo ndipo alibe mwayi wofotokoza maganizo awo.

en: Mr. Grignon says greater freedom of expression would strengthen Rwanda's reconciliation process and enhance its chances of a peaceful future.
ny: Bambo Grignon akuti ufulu waukulu wa kulankhula udzalimbitsa njira ya chiyanjanitso ya Rwanda ndi kuwonjezera mwayi wake wa tsogolo lamtendere.

en: He says the international community's involvement in reconstruction projects gives it the leverage to make this plain to the Rwandan government.
ny: Iye akuti kugwirizana kwa mayiko m'ntchito zomanganso kumapatsa mphamvu kuti boma la Rwanda lizimvetsetsa zimenezi.

en: Rwanda Welcomes the Arrest of Former Rebel Leader
ny: Dziko la Rwanda Latamanda Mtsogoleri Wakale Wopanduka

en: Rwandas Justice Minister said his government is pleased with the arrest Monday of a former rebel leader accused of masterminding genocide and violating human rights against Rwandans and Congolese villagers in 1994.
ny: Nduna ya za chilungamo ya Rwanda inati boma lake likukondwera ndi kumangidwa Lolemba kwa mtsogoleri wakale wa zigawenga yemwe akuimbidwa mlandu woyambitsa kupha anthu ndi kuphwanya ufulu wa anthu ku Rwanda ndi kumidzi ya ku Congo mu 1994.

en: French authorities arrested Callixte Mbarushimana, a former leader of the infamous Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda (FDLR), an ethnic Hutu rebel group.
ny: Akuluakulu a boma la France anamanga Callixte Mbarushimana, yemwe anali mtsogoleri wa gulu lotchuka la Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda (FDLR), gulu lopanduka la Ahutu.

en: Tharcisse Karugarama welcomed the decision of French authorities to enforce the international arrest warrant issued by his government and the International Criminal Court (ICC) against the former rebel leader.
ny: Tharcisse Karugarama analandira bwino chigamulo cha akuluakulu a boma la France chopereka chigamulo cha kumangidwa kwa dziko lonse choperekedwa ndi boma lake ndi International Criminal Court (ICC) motsutsana ndi mtsogoleri wakale wa zigawenga.

en: "It is good news that Callixte Mbarushimana has been (arrested) by the French judicial authority. Good news in the sense that, first, there was an international arrest warrant against him issued by the Rwandan government in respect of (the alleged) act of genocide committed in Rwanda in 1994."
ny: "Ndi nkhani yabwino kuti Callixte Mbarushimana (wamangidwa) ndi akuluakulu a boma la France. Nkhani yabwino ndi yakuti, choyamba, panali lamulo la kumangidwa kwa mayiko onse lochokera ku boma la Rwanda chifukwa cha (kuganiza) za kuphedwa kwa anthu ku Rwanda mu 1994. "

en: Karugarama said the Hague-based court sought the arrest of the former rebel leader who was believed to be hiding in France.
ny: Karugarama anati khoti la ku Hague linkafuna kumanga mtsogoleri wakale wa zigawenga amene ankakhulupirira kuti anali kubisala ku France.

en: Genocide memorial in Rwanda
ny: Msonkhano wokumbukira kuphedwa kwa anthu ku Rwanda

en: "The International Criminal Court (ICC) conducted its own investigation about his other activities and they found sufficient evidence to support the charge of war crimes and crimes against humanity perpetrated in the DRC and they issued an arrest warrant, which the French judicial authorities have executed."
ny: "Bwalo Lalikulu la International Criminal Court (ICC) linafufuza za ntchito zake zina ndipo linapeza umboni wokwanira wotsimikizira mlandu wa milandu yankhondo ndi milandu yolimbana ndi umunthu yomwe inachitika ku DRC ndipo linapereka chilolezo chomanga, chomwe akuluakulu a milandu a ku France anakwaniritsa".

en: The Hague-based court accused Mbarushimana and other rebels in the FDLR of using violence against unarmed civilians as their main tool in a campaign to forcefully obtain political power for the rebel group.
